awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Modeling the Longitudinal Career Pathways of Engineering Doctorates by Gender, Race/Ethnicity, and Discipline
awd_abstract_narration:
The advanced training of diverse engineering doctoral students is critical to the nation's potential for technological innovation, ability to meet workforce demands, and general prosperity and welfare. An understanding of the longer-term career paths of engineering PhDs has important implications for increasing academic persistence among engineering doctoral students, as well as informing the design of PhD programs and interventions to help prepare doctoral students for a multitude of careers in education, business, industry, and government. This integrated research and education project examines how individual factors, institutional structures, and environmental contexts converge at the PhD level to model and explain the longitudinal career patterns of engineering PhDs. By examining whether there are differences in career paths by gender, race/ethnicity, and engineering discipline, this research project will render important contextual information for various applications, such as the creation of engineering workforce policy, development of strategies that promote a competitive engineering workforce, and ways to strengthening academic-industry partnerships. The findings will provide doctoral programs with critical and actionable information for developing and enhancing training that accounts for the realities of workforce demands and student career preferences.  

The theoretical approach highlights the experiences of individuals at the intersection of gender, race/ethnicity, and engineering discipline rather than aggregating individuals in a monolithic group or aggregating engineering with science, technology, and mathematics fields. Informed by social cognitive career, life course, and intersectionality theories, this comprehensive examination of the longer-term career patterns of engineering doctoral graduates focuses on identifying employment patterns and transitions as a function of important demographic characteristics and doctoral education experiences using quantitative regression analyses on nationally-representative data. Through individual interviews, this research project will also pinpoint why doctoral graduates pursued certain career paths and illustrate how their individual choices intersect with institutional and environmental factors. The research project also includes a strong dissemination strategy designed for broad and meaningful impact across communities, including academic, professional, and student services associations, and industry. Specifically, the research project includes a plan for developing a professional development workshop using an integrated case study and video vignette approach to provide engineering doctoral students and early career PhDs with tools and training for longer-range career planning.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The role of graduate education in the workforce continues to receive growing attention. Increased understanding of doctorates’ career trajectories has implications for the design of graduate programs and the preparation of doctoral students for the workforce. This integrated research and education program examined the longitudinal career patterns of engineering doctorates using nationally representative datasets from the National Science Foundation. Prospective and current doctoral students can leverage the research findings to more accurately assess their long-term career prospects. Graduate programs can apply the research findings toward developing programs and enhancing training that resonate with workforce demands and student career preferences. Research findings can be applied toward policy formation and to the design of new strategies to support doctoral students’ professional development and employment success. 

Intellectual Merit. The integration of multiple theoretical perspectives, analytical approaches, and complementary data sources have contributed to a boundary-spanning examination of engineering doctorates’ longitudinal career pathways. Using data from the National Science Foundation Survey of Doctorate Recipients, research findings indicate an increase in the number of engineering PhDs pursuing postdoctoral research positions (postdocs). Compared to their counterparts, engineering PhDs who participate in postdocs are more likely to have greater research experience, to have graduated from a PhD department with a relatively higher research ranking, and to have graduated from a PhD program with more recent PhDs pursuing similar career trajectories. The potential benefit of postdocs, compared to nonacademic positions, is a higher likelihood of attaining a tenure track faculty positions. Descriptive and multinomial logit regression analyses illustrate that the ten-year career paths of engineering PhDs are not linear and that transitions among different employment sectors (academic, government, and industry) commonly occur. The research findings help extend the knowledge base by identifying factors that influence engineering PhD career trajectories, as well as help inform future studies in engineering graduate education and career outcomes.

Broader Impacts. This research project has resulted in five peer-reviewed journal articles, seven conference presentations, and eight invited seminars and panels. The dissemination strategy has centered around reaching the scholarly community interested in doctoral education through journal publications and presentations, as well as engagement with organizations and stakeholders focused on graduate education and professional development of postdoctoral research scholars. The educational strand has helped further the use of case studies as a pedagogical tool. This project has also helped support the development of research skills among postdoctoral scholars and graduate students, as well as provided opportunities to mentor other PhD students through invited seminars. The research findings have received media attention, and have been featured in several venues focused on doctoral education for broad reach across scholars, practitioners, and other stakeholders. The findings have the potential to transform the approaches and strategies to prepare doctoral engineering students for a changing work environment. The research findings provide important context and information for strengthening partnerships between academia and industry, and providing prospective and current students information on the multitude of career paths available to doctorates. 


Last Modified: 12/13/2024
Modified by: Joyce B Main
